context_meta.title: New artificial intelligence technique dramatically improves the quality of medical imaging
context_meta.summary: "An essential part of the clinical imaging pipeline is image reconstruction, which transforms the raw data coming off the scanner into images for radiologists to evaluate," says Bo Zhu, PhD, a research fellow in the MGH Martinos Center and first author of the Nature paper. "The conventional approach to image reconstruction uses a chain of handcrafted signal processing modules that require expert manual parameter tuning and often are unable to handle imperfections of the raw data, such as noise. "With AUTOMAP, we've taught imaging systems to 'see' the way humans learn to see after birth, not through directly programming the brain but by promoting neural connections to adapt organically through repeated training on real-world examples," Zhu explains.

context_meta.title: IG Group boosted by punters piling into cryptocurrency derivatives
context_meta.summary: The recent mania surrounding digital currencies such as Bitcoin helped trading company IG Group hit its best quarter ever as thousands of people were attracted by the currency's huge price rises.  The FTSE 250 business said on Thursday that it made £1,482 per client in the three months to February 28, 25pc more than the previous year, with trading in cryptocurrencies making up 11pc of its revenues compared to just 1pc a year earlier. Interest in Bitcoin rocketed last year after the value of the currency surged from under $1,000 (£709) at the start of 2017 to almost $20,000 (£14,180) in December, with IG Group recording 12,500 clients who traded for the first time during the period.  However the frenzy is already dwindling after investors were spooked by the currency's recent drops in value, with IG Group noting that cryptocurrency trading has "slowed markedly" since the end of January. Bitcoin this evening was trading at $8,601, 56pc less than its peak.  While investors have been concerned about a global crackdown on digital currencies, few have been put off by the clampdown on the spreadbetting industry. The European Securities and Markets Authority (Esma) is due to publish a swathe of strict measures for the sector with the aim of protecting inexperienced investors.  The company said that while any impact from the new rules are unlikely to be felt in 2018 "it remains difficult to predict what impact regulatory change may have on the business in subsequent financial years".   The UK's Financial Conduct Authority (FCA) sent a damning letter to industry bosses earlier this year after uncovering "areas of serious concern" in the sector following a year-long review. The majority of retail investors (76pc) lost money on so-called contracts for difference trades between July 2015 and June 2016, the FCA said.

The spending package, expected to be publicly unveiled on Wednesday, includes $380 million to provide states with grants that would help them purchase more secure voting machines and improve election cyber security training. If adopted, the funding will represent the first concrete steps from Congress to bolster election security following a 2016 presidential campaign marred by allegations of Russian meddling.

context_meta.title: The fairly straightforward reason minor league baseball players deserve more money
context_meta.summary: In December of 1999, one of the few protections in place for minor-league baseball players put left-hander Johan Santana on the Twins. Santana, at that point, had never pitched above Class A ball, but had been in the Astros' system long enough to be subject to the Rule 5 Draft, which exists to prevent clubs from stashing Major League-ready players in their farm systems for too long. The rebuilding Minnesota Twins saw something they liked in Santana — in retrospect, it's not hard to figure out what — and scooped up Santana (with an assist from the Marlins) on the day of that draft. Players selected in the Rule 5 Draft must remain on the 25-man roster of their new teams for an entire season or be returned to their original organizations, so the Twins held on to Santana even though he was outright terrible in 2000.

Under the old law, farmers, manufacturers and other businesses could swap certain "property" assets – such as trucks and machinery – without immediately paying taxes on the difference in value. The 2017 tax overhaul inserted the word "real" before "property." With that, the provision now applies only to real estate swaps. context_meta.title: 'Justice League' Was A Sad Failure In Studio Leadership
context_meta.summary: Warner Bros.' big-budget superhero team-up event film Justice League has finally completed its theatrical run worldwide, and is available on home entertainment. With $656 million in global receipts, the film became one of the year's biggest financial disappointments at the box office and another poorly received entry in the studio's struggling attempts to get their shared DC Comics cinematic universe on firmer footing. While there are plenty of factors contributing to Justice League's inglorious financial outcome, the bottom line is this: the film's failure was due to a failure in leadership. A combination of overall bad reviews and weak audience grades hurt Justice League's performance, as did the baggage it carried from the troubled critical and audience reception of its direct narrative predecessor Batman v Superman (which I'll always defend as being far, far better than its reputation).

context_meta.summary: In 1949 Donald Hebb's pioneering work suggested that learning occurs in the brain by modifying the strength of the synapses, whereas neurons function as the computational elements in the brain. Using new theoretical results and experiments on neuronal cultures, a group of scientists, led by Prof. Ido Kanter, of the Department of Physics and the Gonda (Goldschmied) Multidisciplinary Brain Research Center at Bar-Ilan University, has demonstrated that the central assumption for nearly 70 years that learning occurs only in the synapses is mistaken. In an article published today in the journal Scientific Reports, the researchers go against conventional wisdom to show that learning is actually done by several dendrites, similar to the slow learning mechanism currently attributed to the synapses.
